commit.message:
Refactor the documentation into separate pages (#202)

Break up the usage documentation into separate pages: basic usage
(Training your Pooch with some elements removed), single file downloads,
downloaders, processors, and advanced tricks. Moved the processor and
downloader specifications from the docstring of Pooch.fetch to the
respective pages and link to them from the docstrings. Also did general
updates to the docstrings (for example, to include the new retrieve
function) and tutorials. Separated the side menu into Getting Started,
User Guide, and Reference Documentation like in all other projects.

verification.payload:
tree e6688905ae4bb6c0f836da32fbd66d712a306178
parent d5186a0a59598e5611825466c2f98fd1172ecd00
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1596734669 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1596734669 -0300

Refactor the documentation into separate pages (#202)

Break up the usage documentation into separate pages: basic usage
(Training your Pooch with some elements removed), single file downloads,
downloaders, processors, and advanced tricks. Moved the processor and
downloader specifications from the docstring of Pooch.fetch to the
respective pages and link to them from the docstrings. Also did general
updates to the docstrings (for example, to include the new retrieve
function) and tutorials. Separated the side menu into Getting Started,
User Guide, and Reference Documentation like in all other projects.

commit.message:
Add warning to the docs about dropping Python 3.5 (#201)

Update the README message to say that 1.2.0 is the last to support 3.5.
Add a compatibility table to the Installing page. Some other
improvements to the install instructions (move dependencies to the
bottom and say that they should be installed automatically, add a note
that the testing step is optional, link to Miniconda as well, using
`python -m pip` instead of `pip`, use `git+https://...` instead of the
zip archive to get correct version numbers from versioneer).

verification.payload:
tree 651f5ae053c2ba4fcb6fc615ba3f4cd0557b8440
parent 995af5af7d5951300b22bec9b219b706b5d39303
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1596200018 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1596200018 +0100

commit.message:
Point to Unzip/tar from Decompress docs and errors (#200)

If given a `.zip` or `.tar` archive, `Decompress` will now tell users to
use `Unzip` and `Untar` instead. This clears up the confusion around why
`Decompress` doesn't work with zip files. Add a pointer to the
docstring as well.

verification.payload:
tree 8ed0a9914ee9917c83fb426cbc17270aaec4799e
parent cd183ec7255bbc2e3f59ca2bf0ea1a65a43e5b5e

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1596121410 +0100

Point to Unzip/tar from Decompress docs and errors (#200)

If given a `.zip` or `.tar` archive, `Decompress` will now tell users to
use `Unzip` and `Untar` instead. This clears up the confusion around why
`Decompress` doesn't work with zip files. Add a pointer to the
docstring as well.

commit.message:
Push documentation to GitHub Pages using Actions (#198)

Replace the TravisCI deployment of documentation pages with Actions.
Had to rebuild the docs in the `deploy` workflow since we can't share build
artefacts between workflows at the moment. Implement the script to push
the updated docs here instead of relying on the `continuous-integration` 
repository. This eliminates the need for TravisCI, so also remove the 
configuration file for it.

tree 8a2eb5326c907996fa716aa6ccd1ca3920e280b9

Replace the TravisCI deployment of documentation pages with Actions.
Had to rebuild the docs in the `deploy` workflow since we can't share build
artefacts between workflows at the moment. Implement the script to push
the updated docs here instead of relying on the `continuous-integration` 
repository. This eliminates the need for TravisCI, so also remove the 
configuration file for it.

commit.message:
Add GitHub Actions workflow for publishing to PyPI (#196)

Use a separate workflow that doesn't run on pull requests. Builds the
archives/wheels and pushes to test PyPI on pushes to the master branch
and to PyPI proper on releases. Disable PyPI uploads from TravisCI.

Use a separate workflow that doesn't run on pull requests. Builds the
archives/wheels and pushes to test PyPI on pushes to the master branch
and to PyPI proper on releases. Disable PyPI uploads from TravisCI.

commit.message:
Set up GitHub Actions for testing and linting (#194)

Use Github Actions as a replacement for Azure and TravisCI non-deploy builds. 
Runs faster and was easier to configure. Not using the fatiando/continuous-integration 
scripts but should migrate as soon as those are ready. A lot of those scripts can be
replaced with available Actions. Set up two workflows: 1 for linting and 1 for testing.
The linter workflow runs black, flake8, and pylint in separate jobs we can see which 
tool passes/fails. The tests are run on linux/mac/windows with Python >=3.5. Docs
are uploaded as artefacts for later deployment and visual inspection.

verification.payload:
tree cc0966631ae77986aefea6b451501ea441b5b5ca
parent 2ce6517b10e061b9b1c9f6ae398f78f53d0554f1
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1595851078 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1595851078 +0100

Set up GitHub Actions for testing and linting (#194)

Use Github Actions as a replacement for Azure and TravisCI non-deploy builds. 
Runs faster and was easier to configure. Not using the fatiando/continuous-integration 
scripts but should migrate as soon as those are ready. A lot of those scripts can be
replaced with available Actions. Set up two workflows: 1 for linting and 1 for testing.
The linter workflow runs black, flake8, and pylint in separate jobs we can see which 
tool passes/fails. The tests are run on linux/mac/windows with Python >=3.5. Docs
are uploaded as artefacts for later deployment and visual inspection.

commit.message:
Add the SFTPDownloader class for secure FTP downloads (#165)

Uses the paramiko package (optional dependency) to do the downloads.
Based on FTPDownloader with a few other restrictions (can't accept open
file objects, just file name strings).

verification.payload:
tree e458269f167611a55a7acbcc48a8f84e03be8ade
parent 21b20c769ead3e2fd902dbc321df0ae7bc48c942
author Luke Gregor <luke-gregor@users.noreply.github.com> 1595582233 +0200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1595582233 +0100

Add the SFTPDownloader class for secure FTP downloads (#165)

Uses the paramiko package (optional dependency) to do the downloads.
Based on FTPDownloader with a few other restrictions (can't accept open
file objects, just file name strings).

commit.message:
Test FTP downloads using a local test server (#192)

Using the `pytest-localftpserver` plugin, we can test FTP downloads running on a local server. 
The nice thing is that the plugin just provides a fixture that can access the server so we don't 
have to do much. Added a context manager to move test files to the local server and clean up 
afterwards. The availability test is still relying on a remote server because the local server runs 
on a random port and we don't have a way to control that on `Pooch.is_available` yet.

Fixes #190

verification.payload:
tree 26c5f03cab072cc7206d3f4c13958d3d42a5fa94
parent c2e51dfb63bd751164d83e5bb9d83e49500ea6b6
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1594734792 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1594734792 +0100

Test FTP downloads using a local test server (#192)

Using the `pytest-localftpserver` plugin, we can test FTP downloads running on a local server. 
The nice thing is that the plugin just provides a fixture that can access the server so we don't 
have to do much. Added a context manager to move test files to the local server and clean up 
afterwards. The availability test is still relying on a remote server because the local server runs 
on a random port and we don't have a way to control that on `Pooch.is_available` yet.

Fixes #190

commit.message:
Fix FTP availability check when file in directory (#191)

If the data file is not in the base directory, the Pooch.is_available
test was broken since we were checking for the full path in `ftp.nlst`
instead of just the file name. Using the UNAVCO ftp server revealed this
(ftp://data-out.unavco.org/). The change was made since the one we were
using before started refusing connections on CI.

verification.payload:
tree 4a20ee5fc83ee2eabd4cb9d587e4e7181d253c33
parent 7c7b72cbe684028711af777dbfd162d24d2062cd
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1594390332 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1594390332 +0100

Fix FTP availability check when file in directory (#191)

If the data file is not in the base directory, the Pooch.is_available
test was broken since we were checking for the full path in `ftp.nlst`
instead of just the file name. Using the UNAVCO ftp server revealed this
(ftp://data-out.unavco.org/). The change was made since the one we were
using before started refusing connections on CI.

commit.message:
Delay cache creation until first download (#173)

As seen in recent issues in scikit-image, creating the cache folder in
`pooch.create` can cause problems since this function is called at import time
by our users. This means that importing the package in parallel can cause race
conditions and crashes. To prevent that from happening, delay the creation of
the cache folder until `Pooch.fetch` or `retrieve` are called. Creating the
folder name was factored out of `make_local_storage` into the new function
`cache_location`. Both `fetch` and `retrieve` then use `make_local_storage` to
create the folder while `create` only runs `cache_location`. Since we can't
check if the cache is writable when calling `create`, then it makes more sense
to raise an exception with the message about using the environment variable
instead of a log message (as #150 wanted).

Fixes #172

verification.payload:
tree 377bd39e69b5798095b71b2b4e688b88cdc96cda
parent dd56cd016268ee54473c5c511ab186c4c35923ee
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1589450255 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1589450255 +0100

Delay cache creation until first download (#173)

As seen in recent issues in scikit-image, creating the cache folder in
`pooch.create` can cause problems since this function is called at import time
by our users. This means that importing the package in parallel can cause race
conditions and crashes. To prevent that from happening, delay the creation of
the cache folder until `Pooch.fetch` or `retrieve` are called. Creating the
folder name was factored out of `make_local_storage` into the new function
`cache_location`. Both `fetch` and `retrieve` then use `make_local_storage` to
create the folder while `create` only runs `cache_location`. Since we can't
check if the cache is writable when calling `create`, then it makes more sense
to raise an exception with the message about using the environment variable
instead of a log message (as #150 wanted).

Fixes #172

commit.message:
Bug fix: creating the cache folder in parallel (#171)

Add `exist_ok` to `os.makedirs` in case the cache folder is being created 
in parallel (multiple jobs trying to call `makedirs` at the same time). 
Includes a test case with threads and processes to make sure it works.

Fixes #170 and fixes #150

verification.payload:
tree 0f2a4fdf6cdee8f6218e9474926668784e1628f7
parent 193e04678f5be30e9370fb5671f7a0cde0824d77
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1589024832 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1589024832 +0100

Bug fix: creating the cache folder in parallel (#171)

Add `exist_ok` to `os.makedirs` in case the cache folder is being created 
in parallel (multiple jobs trying to call `makedirs` at the same time). 
Includes a test case with threads and processes to make sure it works.

Fixes #170 and fixes #150

commit.message:
Pin pylint to 2.4.* (#167)

Version 2.5.0 introduced a bug with the multiprocessing option. This
happens often enough that we should have pylint pinned and only upgrade
when we choose to do it. See https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/3524

verification.payload:
tree e6daac85182e946f44464f670309ebb4a078611f
parent 52ff6d808fd71229de6f1161cb2e316c699d9179
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1588839427 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1588839427 +0100

Pin pylint to 2.4.* (#167)

Version 2.5.0 introduced a bug with the multiprocessing option. This
happens often enough that we should have pylint pinned and only upgrade
when we choose to do it. See https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/3524

commit.message:
Add example of creating a registry from remote files (#161)

Sometimes you don't have the files for the registry locally and would have to
download them manually. Add example to the tutorial using the `retrieve` 
function to automate the process. The example covers two cases: when all 
remote files share the same base url and when every file has its own url.

verification.payload:
tree db8feca916b4248167f26201fff0ed14d19923e9
parent acf820c8c68f8d61349185bc8a3f07a1030abfbf
author Santiago Soler <santiago.r.soler@gmail.com> 1586798295 -0300
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1586798295 +0100

Add example of creating a registry from remote files (#161)

Sometimes you don't have the files for the registry locally and would have to
download them manually. Add example to the tutorial using the `retrieve` 
function to automate the process. The example covers two cases: when all 
remote files share the same base url and when every file has its own url.

commit.message:
Add the retrive function to fetch single files (#152)

Add the function `retrieve` for downloading single data files. 
This is much more convenient than setting up a `Pooch`. 
It automatically selects a unique file name and saves files to 
a "pooch" cache (as determined by `os_cache`). Allows 
passing in `known_hash=None` to bypass the hash checks. 
In this case, will print a message with the SHA256 hash of 
the downloaded file and advising users to set `known_hash` 
to this value.

Fixes #147

verification.payload:
tree 1d26f0c581943e355e0e093ef5053168593b4694
parent 3a36c4895c43ff943874cafdf3f48e83c302e4c0
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1586368077 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1586368077 +0100

Add the retrive function to fetch single files (#152)

Add the function `retrieve` for downloading single data files. 
This is much more convenient than setting up a `Pooch`. 
It automatically selects a unique file name and saves files to 
a "pooch" cache (as determined by `os_cache`). Allows 
passing in `known_hash=None` to bypass the hash checks. 
In this case, will print a message with the SHA256 hash of 
the downloaded file and advising users to set `known_hash` 
to this value.

Fixes #147

commit.message:
Don't use temp file name in hash mismatch error (#160)

Fixes a regression introduced in #157 where we started including the
name of the temporary download file in the exception again. Revert back
to including the name of the file in the registry.

verification.payload:
tree c8db0a7560eca69bd806121e01698e0f3e5a0f7a
parent d8965aedf5478f4c194b18b8048dc9aabc4c7dce
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1586359650 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1586359650 +0100

Don't use temp file name in hash mismatch error (#160)

Fixes a regression introduced in #157 where we started including the
name of the temporary download file in the exception again. Revert back
to including the name of the file in the registry.

commit.message:
Separate the streaming code into a function (#159)

Move the code that checks if a file needs to be downloaded, updated, or 
just fetched into a separate function `download_action`. Also move the 
streaming download code into a `stream_download` function. This allows 
both components to be tested independently of the other mechanisms in 
Pooch.

verification.payload:
tree 020763c1d602c5db8bd5a575066d977ee61fd6a5
parent 4f66acf2aec7d9d8f30bf022ec8027f9f58f6f9b
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1585851311 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1585851311 +0100

Separate the streaming code into a function (#159)

Move the code that checks if a file needs to be downloaded, updated, or 
just fetched into a separate function `download_action`. Also move the 
streaming download code into a `stream_download` function. This allows 
both components to be tested independently of the other mechanisms in 
Pooch.

commit.message:
Move all hash checking to hash_matches (#157)

Including the exception raising controlled by new parameter `strict`.
This removes the need for re-calculating the new hash just so we can
include it in the error message. The hash calculation can be heavy
for large files so we don't want to do it twice. Also improve the error
message to include the hash algorithm and suggest what went wrong.

verification.payload:
tree 392a6389b54f8da9588f2a3e15a1a5366c2d5ee6
parent 7ffbc4f5bfd0051f1ab876aa523dad2d0194dbd8
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1585844674 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1585844674 +0100

Move all hash checking to hash_matches (#157)

Including the exception raising controlled by new parameter `strict`.
This removes the need for re-calculating the new hash just so we can
include it in the error message. The hash calculation can be heavy
for large files so we don't want to do it twice. Also improve the error
message to include the hash algorithm and suggest what went wrong.

commit.message:
Move downloader choice to a separate function (#156)

The code that chooses the appropriate downloader for the given url
doesn't depend on anything else in `pooch/core.py`. Move it to
`pooch/downloaders.py` to test it separately from the `Pooch` class and
avoid importing downloaders at all in `pooch/core.py`. Move the
downloader specific tests to a separate file as well so it matches the
tests for processors better (in a separate file instead of in the core
tests).

verification.payload:
tree bfc91a18572a7ccc2f03c18d80f59f515cb582b2
parent d5727a396bb98e09c814d73db2aa7757462900cc
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1585817621 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1585817621 +0100

Move downloader choice to a separate function (#156)

The code that chooses the appropriate downloader for the given url
doesn't depend on anything else in `pooch/core.py`. Move it to
`pooch/downloaders.py` to test it separately from the `Pooch` class and
avoid importing downloaders at all in `pooch/core.py`. Move the
downloader specific tests to a separate file as well so it matches the
tests for processors better (in a separate file instead of in the core
tests).

commit.message:
Explicitly set PR trigger for all branches on Azure (#153)

For some reason, Azure Pipelines CI wasn't starting up o PRs, only on
master and tags. Explicitly setting a trigger for PRs against any branch
seems to work.

verification.payload:
tree cbebbe204796dedba5ceff019599ee76af14a1d6
parent 077f9b1cd78b44047c01f59d1ec90778cb315e40
author Leonardo Uieda <leouieda@gmail.com> 1584382765 +0000
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1584382765 +0000

Explicitly set PR trigger for all branches on Azure (#153)

For some reason, Azure Pipelines CI wasn't starting up o PRs, only on
master and tags. Explicitly setting a trigger for PRs against any branch
seems to work.

commit.message:
Refactor code for checking the file hash (#151)

Move code from methods to 2 dedicated functions: one to check the hash
algorithm and the other to check that the hash matches a known hash.
The hash algorithm defaults to sha256 and hash checking functions knows
to ignore the algorithm part of the hash when checking (if needed).
This simplifies the class by removing the need to add algorithms to all
hashes (retaining the legacy behaviour) and removing some duplicated
code for calculating hashes in the Pooch class.

Move code from methods to 2 dedicated functions: one to check the hash
algorithm and the other to check that the hash matches a known hash.
The hash algorithm defaults to sha256 and hash checking functions knows
to ignore the algorithm part of the hash when checking (if needed).
This simplifies the class by removing the need to add algorithms to all

code for calculating hashes in the Pooch class.
